About Me

Hi, my name is James. I recently graduated from Warren Wilson College in Asheville, North Carolina, earning a BS in Biology and a BS in Chemistry. Throughout college and high school, I developed interests and skills in conservation genetics, human genomics, and statistical modeling. I enjoy creative programming and data visualizations, including developing applications in Python and Shiny.

In January 2020, I moved to from Virginia to Pomona, California. I am excited to explore the West Coast!

Publications

Webb et al. (2017). Molecular Genetic Influences on Normative and Problematic Alcohol Use in a Population-Based Sample of College Students. Frontiers in Genetics, 8

Selected Projects

The TopoTable Project

jkitchensf16.shinyapps.io/topotable

The goal of the TopoTable Project is to create a dynamic 3D topographic relief table that is built with moveable pillars. Rather than constraining it to a single region, the motors within the TopoTable would allow it to seamlessly shift from one map to the next. I have developed the user interface for downloading and processing elevation data using Python, R, Leaflet and Shiny. This application is hosted through shinyapps.io.

Marine Tardigrades of the World

paul-bartels.shinyapps.io/marine-tardigrades

In October 2019, Dr. Paul Bartels and I collaborated to develop a Shiny application that would display aggregated marine tardigrade findings from Kaczmarek, L., Bartels, P.J., Roszkowska, M. & Nelson, D. (2015). The Zoogeography of Marine Tardigrada, Zootaxa 4037:1-189. Using R, this application accesses data through the Google Sheets API, allowing for quick and efficient updating of findings without the need for a full redeploy. Findings are then displayed within a Leaflet map, hosted through shinyapps.io.

Research Experience

Science Systems and Applications, Inc - Jet Propulsion Laboratory

www.ssaihq.com

NASA Develop Intern

January 2020 to April 2020

Through a collaboration between the California Department of Water Resources, California State University - Los Angeles, and NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, my project team tested the feasibility of using Remote Sensing datasets to supplement in-situ well and GPS measurements for the purpose of quantifying groundwater storage changes in the Central Valley. Modeling was performed in Python and R. We started development of a Shiny application (VIRGO) to aid Groundwater Sustainability Agency managers in their assessment of current conditions and trends.

Warren Wilson College Genetics and Plant Physiology Research Laboratory

Research Assistant

September 2017 to December 2019

While at Warren Wilson College, I worked as a research assistant within Dr. Alisa Hove’s laboratory, where we studied human-impacted species, including the American pika (Ochotona princeps) and American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius). My capstone project was a genetic sex ratio analysis of American pika populations found in the Rocky Mountain Region. Working with samples collected by partners at University of Colorado Boulder, I created a protocol for DNA Extraction and Quantification from pika hair, tissue, and scat samples. Preliminary findings suggested that there was a slight male bias across our samples. Continued observation and further testing are still needed to determine if this bias is apparent within the population or due to inadvertent effects of the sampling methodology. Through work in the lab, I advanced my skills in PCR, Gel Electrophoresis, NMR Spectroscopy, Field Sampling and Phenological Monitoring.

Mathematical and Theoretical Biology Institute - Arizona State University

mtbi.asu.edu

Summer Research Intern

June 2019 to July 2019

I worked as a research intern during an eight week summer term at Arizona State University. The first four weeks of the program included guest lectures on complex mathematical topics and their application to biological research. The last four weeks focused on the development of an original research project. I was the creator and lead for a team studying the Topography and Behavior Based Movement Modeling for Missing Hikers in Land-Wilderness Settings, including the development of Cellular Automata simulations in Python. We analyzed how certain terrain features generate natural bottlenecking effects, which may funnel a lost hiker in more predictable directions. Knowledge of these effects could potentially aid in efficient search efforts across terrain that is less familiar to search and rescue teams.

University of Wisconsin - La Crosse

www.uwlax.edu/mathematics

Summer Research Intern

May 2018 to August 2018

Paired with professors from UW - La Crosse and members of the United States Geological Survey, I used Environmental DNA data to model population size of an invasive species (Petromyzon marinus) within the Great Lakes. A graduate student at the university had previously collected the data, which included sample extraction and quantitative PCR measurements. I developed models in R to analyze both copy number measurements and presence/absence observations. I found that environmental DNA was strongly correlated with population size in a very controlled setting, such as a pool, but had limited use beyond presence/absence detection when utilized in a natural setting due to the more complex system of compounding factors. Through this project, I gained experience in Statistical Programming.

Virginia Institute for Psychiatric and Behavioral Genetics - Virginia Commonwealth University

vipbg.vcu.edu

Research Assistant

May 2014 to February 2016

I managed a database of over 6000 individuals who participated in the “Spit for Science Project” at Virginia Commonwealth University. I wrote programs in Python and SQLite to query the database and create summary statistics tables describing the available data. These tables included quality control measurements and were used to generate phenotypic risk scores for individuals based on their combination of single nucleotide polymorphisms. With the support of this work, I coauthored Webb et al. (2017). Molecular Genetic Influences on Normative and Problematic Alcohol Use in a Population-Based Sample of College Students. Frontiers in Genetics, 8, where we identified two DNA markers that were significantly associated with alcohol consumption behaviors.

Education

Warren Wilson College

BS Biology & BS Chemistry, Honors

August 2016 to December 2019

During my time at Warren Wilson College, I developed passion for research focused around the conservation of at-risk populations and resources. I worked for three years in Dr. Alisa Hove’s Genetics and Plant Physiology Research Laboratory, studying the population genetics of human impacted species (Ochotona princeps and Panax quinquefolius).

I volunteered in the WWC Creative Technologies Laboratory, assisting students with 3D Printing and establishing a protocol for basic 3-axis CNC Router function. I continued to push myself to learn new and creative methods in data visualization in Python, R, and GIS.

I also volunteered with Bounty and Soul, a local food pantry based out of Black Mountain, North Carolina. While there, I helped run the weekly markets, where we redistributed food donated by various businesses to members of the community. Black Mountain has a prominent Latinx community, and I assisted in translating recipes and questionnaires into Spanish to ensure that all individuals could benefit and be heard.
